3. Tim instrument of communication, e.g. a radio or television transmitter,
a printing press, a movie camera, is merely an instrument. It is
effective or ineffective, moral or immoral, shoddy or exalted, in direct
proportion to the skill, the understanding, the resources, the motives,
and the morals of those who control and operate it. (Today many edu¬
cators and critics stallmake the absurd error made by their predecessors
in judging radio. They decry the product they see on certain commercial
screens—and then reason that television is "bad® instead of understand¬
ing that the given program merely reflects management, resource and policy.)
b. ftess corroiunicaticn" is in many ways an unfortunate term. "Mass" means
many things to many people. It has semantic value significance to
, same of the erudite which tends to make them regard any really large
group of listeners or viewers as a somehow degraded group. Excellence
and appreciation of excellence is construed to be possible only when
the numbers of audience are small and specialized. It is an unfortunate
and loose generalization.
5. The economics of mass media devices make it perfectly apparent that any
"mass communication" whether it be radio, newspaper or television must
reach groups of people whose total numbers can be measured in thousands
of units and not scores of units. The necessary capital outlay and cost
of operation of these devices, even in their simplest forms, make this
measure of audience a requirement and a necessity; otherwise more tra¬
ditional farms of communication, e.g. books, classes, discussion groups,
etc. must be employed.
